Chandan Singh vs The State Of M.P. Judgement Given By: ... on 9 May, 2014

IN THE HIGH COURT OF MADHYA PRADESH, JABALPUR

SINGLE BENCH : HON'BLE MR. JUSTICE N.K.GUPTA, J.

                 Criminal Appeal No.2343/1997

                            Chandan Singh

                                VERSUS

                      State of Madhya Pradesh
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
      Shri Sankalp Kochar, counsel for the appellant.
      Shri Akshay Namdeo, Panel Lawyer for the State/
respondent.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
                         J U D G M E N T

(Delivered on the 9th day of May, 2014) Being aggrieved with the judgment dated 24.10.1997 passed by the learned Special Judge under SC/ST (Prevention of Atrocities) Act, Panna in Special case No.34/1997, the appellant has preferred the present appeal, whereby the appellant was convicted for offence punishable under Sections 376 (1) of IPC and Section 3 (1) (xi) of SC/ST (Prevention of Atrocities) Act (hereinafter it will be referred to as "Special Act") and sentenced for 7 years rigorous imprisonment with fine of Rs.2,000/- and 5 years rigorous imprisonment with fine of Rs.200/- respectively. In default of payment of fine, one year's simple imprisonment and 2 months simple imprisonment respectively was also directed.

-:- 2 -:-

                                                    
Criminal Appeal No.2343 of 1997
2. The prosecution's case, in short, is that, on 2.8.1996, at about 5 p.m. in the evening, the prosecutrix (P.W.2) was coming back from the flour mill carrying her wheat flour in village Tai (Police Station Amaanganj, District Panna). On the way, near a dilapidated house, the appellant restrained her and took her in that dilapidated house. He threw her on the Earth and committed rape upon her. The prosecutrix shouted and therefore, Sunder (P.W.6) and Munni Lal (P.W.7) reached to the spot. They saw the appellant running from the spot. Thereafter, the prosecutrix went to her house. Since her husband Sukhnandi (P.W.4) was out of Station, she could not lodge the FIR. When the husband of the prosecutrix came to the house, the prosecutrix went with him to the Police Station A.J.K., Panna and lodged the FIR Ex.P/2. She was referred for her medico legal examination. Dr. Meena Namdeo (P.W.3) examined the prosecutrix and gave her report, Ex.P/4. Two slides of the vaginal swab were prepared and after sealing them, sent for their forensic science analysis. After due investigation, the charge-sheet was filed before the Special Judge, Panna.
3. The appellant abjured his guilt. He took a plea that he was falsely implicated in the matter due to political enmity. In defence, Hari Bai (D.W.1) was examined.

-:- 3 -:-

                                                    
Criminal Appeal No.2343 of 1997
4. The learned Special Judge after considering the evidence adduced by the parties, convicted and sentenced the appellant as mentioned above.
5. I have heard the learned counsel for the parties.
6. Now a days, it is a settled view of Hon'ble the Apex Court that no corroboration of medical evidence is required to believe the testimony of the prosecutrix. It could be believed on overall assessment of her testimony. The learned counsel for the appellant has submitted that the prosecutrix told that the appellant committed "Bura Kaam", which is not sufficient to establish offence under Section 376 of IPC. In that respect, the learned counsel for the appellant has placed his reliance upon the judgment passed by single Bench of this Court in case of "Kailash Vs. State of Madhya Pradesh" [(1990) (1) M.P.W.N. Note 56], in which it is held that if the prosecutrix had told about Bura Kaam then, only by that terminology, it cannot be presumed that rape was committed upon her. It was contended by the learned counsel for the appellant that the prosecutrix told about Bura Kaam and therefore, it cannot presumed that any intercourse was done with her. However, such contention cannot be accepted. The prosecutrix in para 3 of her statement has stated that the appellant inserted his penis in her vagina and therefore, she had explained about Bura
-:- 4 -:-
                                                    
Criminal Appeal No.2343 of 1997 Kaam done with her. Under such circumstances, the order passed in case of Kailash (supra) cannot be applied in the present case. The learned counsel for the appellant has also submitted that looking to the evidence of the prosecutrix either the appellant is falsely implicated in the matter or the prosecutrix was a consenting party. No resistance is done by her. In this connection, reliance is placed on the judgment passed by the single Bench of this Court in case of "Bharat Vs. State of Madhya Pradesh", [(III) 1992 (1) Crimes Page 880], in which it was held that if no resistance was put by the prosecutrix then, she can be considered as consenting party. The learned counsel for the appellant has also placed his reliance upon the judgment passed by the Division Bench of this Court in case of "Pavinder Ahluwalia Vs. State of Madhya Pradesh", [I.L.R. (2009) M.P. 3426] to show that no crime of rape was made out.
7. In the present case, it is true that the prosecutrix (P.W.2) was 20 years old married woman and therefore, if she was consented then, no offence would be made out against the appellant. The prosecutrix (P.W.2) has stated that the appellant took her in a dilapidated house and thereafter, threw her on the Earth and committed rape upon her. On her shouting, Munni Lal (P.W.7) and Suwan (P.W.6) came to the spot who saw the appellant who was running
-:- 5 -:-
                                                    
Criminal Appeal No.2343 of 1997 from the spot. However, Suwan (P.W.6) and Munni Lal (P.W.7) were examined before the trial Court and they turned hostile. They refused to accept that they saw the incident or they saw the appellant who was running from the spot or they were intimated by the prosecutrix about the incident.
8. The incident took place on 2.8.1996 and the FIR was lodged on 5.8.1996, at about 10 p.m. in the night. The prosecutrix (P.W.2) and her husband Sukhnandi (P.W.4) gave various explanations about the delay caused in lodging the FIR. It was told by these witnesses that Sukhnandi was out of station. When he came to his house back, he was informed by his wife and on the same very day, he had lodged the FIR. The prosecutrix and Sukhnandi took a new ground for delay in lodging the FIR that a Panchayat was called by Sukhnandi and nothing could be decided in that Panchayat and therefore, he had lodged the FIR. There was no description of such Panchayat given in the FIR, Ex.P/2 and therefore, it would be apparent that the prosecutrix as well as her husband Sukhnandi are telling a falsehood about the Panchayat. Sukhnandi and the prosecutrix have accepted that they were working in the fields of grandmother of the appellant and thereafter, Sukhnandi resigned from that job. It was alleged that they had stolen some grains of Masoor and therefore, they were ousted from the job. In this
-:- 6 -:-
                                                    
Criminal Appeal No.2343 of 1997 connection, Baijnath (P.W.9) has stated that a Panchayat took place in which he also participated. However, this witness has stated against his case diary statement about the facts of Panchayat, whereas the witness Indel Singh (P.W.8) has turned hostile. He refused that any Panchayat took place in the village. Since there is no description of Panchayat in the FIR, therefore, it appears that the prosecutrix and her husband cooked a story of Panchayat and Baijnath is a tutored witness, who cannot be believed.
9. Under such circumstances, where Sukhnandi husband of the prosecutrix could not show any satisfactory reason for delay in lodging the FIR then, crime was committed on 2nd August, Sukhnandi came on 3rd August and according to him, he has lodged the FIR in the evening of that day or at the most on the next day and therefore, FIR could be lodged on 4.8.1996 but, it was lodged on 5.8.1996 i.e. 3 days after the incident. Hence, the FIR was delayed and due to delay in FIR, the prosecution's story comes in the clouds of doubt. Since the FIR was lodged with delay of 3 days then, if any symptom of violence could be found on the person of the prosecutrix, they would have disappeared within 3 days and therefore, Dr. Meena Namdeo (P.W.3) did not find anything medically in support of the allegation made by the prosecutrix. However, a report of Forensic Science
-:- 7 -:-
                                                    
Criminal Appeal No.2343 of 1997 Laboratory, Ex.P/14 was received but no semen or sperm particles were found in the vaginal swab of the prosecutrix. Since the medico legal examination was done after 3 days of the incident and the prosecutrix was a married woman therefore, it was possible that in the course of 3 days, all the semen and sperm particles must have flown away and nothing could be obtained in the vaginal swab of the prosecutrix. Hence, nothing positive could be received from medical evidence.
10. Under such circumstances, the testimony of the prosecutrix could be considered on the basis of other circumstances. The prosecutrix and her husband have admitted that they were in the job with grandmother of the appellant and they left that job. Under such circumstances, possibility of enmity cannot be ruled out. The prosecutrix has admitted in para 20 that the grandmother of the appellant was a foul mouth person and she alleged a theft against the prosecutrix and her husband and therefore, they left the job. Similarly, the prosecutrix has accepted in para 21 that Indel Singh, maternal uncle of the prosecutrix fought an election in which the husband of the prosecutrix has also filed his nomination as candidate. Thereafter, her husband dropped his nomination in support of Munna Baniya and thereafter, the election took place between Indel Singh and
-:- 8 -:-
                                                    
Criminal Appeal No.2343 of 1997 Munna Baniya and in that election, Indel Singh lost the election and therefore, a political enmity is also visible in the present case and it is to be seen as to whether the appellant is falsely implicated in the matter due to that political enmity.
11. The prosecutrix (P.W.2) has stated that she went to the house of the appellant and had a talk with his mother to inform her about the incident but, there was no corroboration found to that fact. The prosecutrix has accepted that place of incident, a dilapidated house was within the township and none came on her shouting to the spot. The prosecutrix has stated before the trial Court that initially the appellant demanded for some wheat flour and thereafter, took her to the dilapidated house with the pretext that he wants to talk with the prosecutrix but, such facts were not told by the prosecutrix in her case diary statement.

It is told by the prosecutrix that in a narrow lane, the appellant fixed his feet on the wall and stopped her but, no such fact was either mentioned in the FIR, Ex.P/2 or in the case diary statement of the prosecutrix. The prosecutrix has stated that the appellant took half an hour in completion of that intercourse and she resisted. There was some fodder lying in that dilapidated house. However, some abrasions were caused to her knees and both of her shoulders were

-:- 9 -:-

                                                    
Criminal Appeal No.2343 of 1997 also bruised, whereas Dr.Meena Namdeo did not find any such injury on her knees as well as on her shoulders.
12. The prosecutrix and her husband Sukhnandi has accepted that they went alongwith Baijnath Zamindar to the premises of the Court and Munna Baniya also accompanied them. A written complaint was typed in the Court. The prosecutrix did not know as to who typed that complaint.

Thereafter, they went to the office of S.P. but, he was not available and therefore, on the next day, they met the S.P. concerned, who informed the SHO, Police Station A.J.K. on phone and therefore, they went to the Police Station A.J.K., where the concerned investigation officer kept that written report and a report was written on the basis of that written report. If the FIR, Ex.P/2 is perused then, it would be apparent that the FIR is nothing but, a copy of that written report. Though written report was not annexed with the charge-sheet. Under such circumstances, it would be apparent that the report was prepared by some law knowing person in delayed manner and at the time of preparation of the report, Munna Baniya rival of Indel Singh, uncle of the appellant was also present to create such a report. The prosecutrix has accepted that when the appellant was arrested, she was informed that she will get a sum of Rs.25,000/- but, nothing has been received by her till her

-:- 10 -:-

                                                    
Criminal Appeal No.2343 of 1997 statement. Sukhnandi has accepted that he was informed at the time of lodging the FIR that in case of rape, he would get a sum of Rs.50,000/-. He received a cheque of Rs.25,000/-, which was lying in the house. He does not know as to how the cheque can be drawn. Looking to the statement of the prosecutrix and her husband, it appears that the FIR could have been lodged due to instigation of Munna Baniya to get some compensation. Under such circumstances, possibility cannot be ruled out that the appellant was falsely implicated in the matter due to instigation of Munna Baniya and to get the compensation.
13. If the statement of the prosecutrix is considered as a whole then, it would be apparent that though the place of incident was in a dense locality but, nobody came after hearing her hue and cry, which indicates that the prosecutrix did not make any hue and cry. Secondly that dilapidated house was 21 feet away from the main road and therefore, the prosecutrix could refuse to go inside that house or she could shout when the appellant was dragging her into the house but, she did nothing to resist against her dragging. Thirdly, she did not tell about the incident to anyone like Kotwar, Chowkidar or any other officer of village.

Her husband came on the next day evening but, the FIR was not lodged on the third day of the incident but, it was lodged

-:- 11 -:-

                                                    
Criminal Appeal No.2343 of 1997 with delay of 3 days. Her statements are contradictory to the facts mentioned in the FIR. Also, no medical support was found in corroboration of statement of the prosecutrix. Even in the vaginal swab, no sperm or semen particles were found. There was enmity between the grandmother of the appellant and the prosecutrix that she was removed from her job from the fields of the grandmother of the appellant. Also, there is a political enmity between the husband of the prosecutrix and uncle of the appellant. If all such discrepancies are considered then, it would be apparent that either the prosecutrix was a consenting party or no intercourse was committed by the appellant upon her. In both the results, no offence punishable under Section 376 of IPC is made out against the appellant and no offence punishable under Section 3 (1) (xi) of SC/ST (Prevention of Atrocities) Act or Section 354 of IPC is made out against the appellant.
14. In this connection, the judgment passed by the Division Bench of this Court in case of Pavinder Ahluwalia (supra) may be referred in which various circumstances were considered and found that the testimony of the prosecutrix cannot be believed. In the light of the aforesaid judgment and looking to the facts and circumstances of the present case, the testimony of the prosecutrix cannot be believed.

-:- 12 -:-

                                                    
Criminal Appeal No.2343 of 1997 The prosecution failed to prove that the appellant had committed any intercourse with the prosecutrix or if it was committed then, it was not with the consent of the prosecutrix.
14. On the basis of the aforesaid discussion, the appeal filed by the appellant appears to be acceptable and therefore, it is hereby allowed. The conviction as well as the sentence directed against the appellant for offence punishable under Section 376 (1) of IPC and Section 3 (1) (xi) of SC/ST (Prevention of Atrocities) Act are hereby set aside.

The appellant is acquitted from all the charges appended against him. He would be entitled to get the fine amount back, if he has deposited the same before the trial Court.

15. The appellant is on bail. His presence is no more required before this Court and therefore, it is directed that his bail bonds shall stand discharged.

18. A copy of the order be sent to the trial Court alongwith its record for information and compliance.

(N.K.GUPTA) JUDGE 9/5/2014 Pushpendra
